section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you’ll need a pile of ten twigs or pipe cleaners to use as twigs, and colored tape to create a one by five grid large enough to hold them on the table.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Bird Builds a Nest, we read about a bird building a nest. We talked about the twigs she carried and how she couldn’t carry too many at once.

In this activity, we will pretend that Bird can carry five twigs at a time. We will check that we have five twigs for Bird to carry by making a 5-frame and filling it in. I will start with a number of twigs, and then ask you how many more we need to get to five twigs.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up As children watch, tape out a 5-frame. As you make it, point out that you are making five spots, one for each twig Bird can carry.

Model Pick up three twigs from the pile. Place one twig each in the first three boxes of the 5-frame. Describe what you are doing as you place the twigs, and then count the three twigs aloud. Ask how many more twigs you would need to have five twigs in all. Count the empty squares aloud and explain that you need two more twigs. Fill in the remaining two twigs and count again.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How many twigs does Bird have? How many more twigs does Bird need to have five twigs in all? Can you fill them in?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Continue the activity until each child has had at least two chances to fill in the frame.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How does a 5-frame help you count numbers? How do you know when you have 5 twigs?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Below each square of the 5-frame, place the corresponding Magnetic Numeral as a way of labeling each box.

Provide children with 10-frames to further extend their counting. Provide story opportunities such as “Bird used eight twigs for her nest.” Then have students represent the number and state the number it takes to get to ten.
Review the numbers one to five, and have children repeat after you. Point to the twigs, or supplies you are using as twigs, to identify them so children understand what to use.
For children struggling to pay attention, have them get up, move around, and act out each number they count by jumping, skipping, or doing another movement that number of times.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you’ll need Two-Color Counters and a 5-frame taped on the table.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Bird Builds a Nest, we learned how Bird builds her nest and solves problems along the way. We’ll practice solving number stories about Bird’s problems using 5-frames.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the word solve. Use the solve Vocabulary Card to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will solve number stories using a 5-frame, which helps us see how many are in five.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Tape a 5-frame to the table and place the Two-Color Counters nearby.

Model Let’s pretend we found two feathers for a nest. Then we found one more. How many feathers do we have in all? We can use the 5-frame to count. Think aloud as you use the 5-frame to count how many feathers you have in all. Explain that each Two-Color Counter represents, or takes the place of, one feather.
Repeat Continue to share number stories about twigs, leaves, feathers, or eggs until each child has practiced counting with the 5-frame at least twice.

Talk About Solving Like counting on fingers, a 5-frame is one tool to help children count and solve math stories. Discuss different strategies children can use to solve math stories on their own. In addition, remind children how to ask an adult for help.
Place the Magnetic Numerals 1–5 under the boxes of the 5-frame. Help children connect the Magnetic Numbers to the total amount of Two-Color Counters shown in the 5-frame.
Have children share their own simple addition problem using the 5-frame and solve it together.
Help native Spanish speakers recognize the cognates problem and problema. Cognates can act as a bridge for multilingual learners between a home language and English.

Explain that there are ways to ask for help with a problem without actually speaking. Demonstrate different non-verbal motions children could use to show they need help, including the American Sign Language sign for help.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you’ll need Two-Color Counters to represent pillows and a 5-frame taped to or set up on the table.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Bird Builds a Nest, we talked about how Bird made the nest cozy. Bird used feathers and grass to make her nest cozy, and people use pillows to make their beds cozy. Let’s figure out how many pillow there are using 5-frames.
In this activity, I will put out Two-Color Counters to represent pillows on a bed. You will say how many there are.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place three Two-Color Counters in the 5-frame.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How many pillows are on this bed? Can you tell just by looking, without counting?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Continue with one to five Counters until each child has a chance to count pillows. You can repeat the activity with blankets or fuzzy slippers to give children extra turns.
Extend Have children show how many pillows they would put on a bed by laying out one to five Counters in the frame and then asking a friend to say the number of pillows.

Talk About Strategies Discuss with children how using the 5-frame helps them count quickly. They might be able to subitize the number of Counters in the frame. They may also know that a full 5-frame (one Counter in each box) tells them there are five in all. In both strategies, children say how many there are in all without counting one-by-one.

Point out that the number of spaces in a 5-frame is always five. A full 5-frame always holds five Counters. Show a full 5-frame and ask, How many? Count each box and count one Counter in each box to show that a full 5-frame always represents a quantity of five.

Use a 10-frame instead of a 5-frame to have children subitize larger numbers. Help them recognize that one row in a 10-frame equals five. They can count on from there, or count the empty boxes backwards from ten to reach a total quickly.
The object that the Two-Color Counters represent is not important for this activity. Choose an object that multilingual learners are familiar and comfortable with.
To miminize wait time, provide each child with a 5-frame and have each child place Counters in their own 5-frame for each number story.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you’ll need a 5-frame and three colors of Connecting Cubes to represent straw, sticks, and bricks. You’ll also need paper and coloring materials.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Three Little Rabbits, we read about the different materials each rabbit used to build a house. Now we’re going to pretend that each rabbit needs five bags full of materials to build each house.
In this activity, I will tell you how many bags of straw, sticks, or bricks the rabbit has. Then you’ll tell me how many more bags the rabbit needs to have five altogether.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Guide children to draw a 5-frame on their own. Assure children that it doesn’t have to look perfect—it just needs to have five boxes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: This rabbit has two bags of sticks. How many more bags does the rabbit need to have five bags in all?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Guide children to put two Connecting Cubes on the 5-frame. Show them how to count the empty boxes to find out how many more bags are needed to have five in all.
Repeat Continue the activity by varying the number of materials the rabbit starts with until children are comfortable with the activity.
Extend Have children make up their own number story and solve it using their 5-frame.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How did you know how many cubes to put in the 5-frame to start? How did you know how many more you would need to get to 5?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Provide children with pre-made 5-frames. Guide them to count each box to check that there are five boxes in all.
Complete the activity using a 10-frame instead of a 5-frame. Revise the story so each rabbit needs 10 bags of materials in all.
Help native Spanish speakers recognize the cognates count and cuenta. Cognates can ease immersion into language and concepts for non-native speakers.
Provide rulers and dotted lines for children struggling to make their 5-frames. Alternately, provide them with a pre-made 5-frame and have them trace each box while counting aloud.
